htmlEmbed:
acronym for Transhumanism, Extropianism, Singularitarianism, Cosmism, Rationalism, Effective Altruism, LongtermismContributors to Wikimedia projects10/1/2023

TESCREAL is an acronym neologism proposed by computer scientist Timnit Gebru and philosopher Émile P. Torres that stands for "transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism".[1][2] Gebru and Torres argue that these ideologies should be treated as an "interconnected and overlapping" group with shared origins.[1] They say this is a movement that allows its proponents to use the threat of human extinction to justify expensive or detrimental projects. They consider it pervasive in social and academic circles in Silicon Valley centered around artificial intelligence.[3] As such, the acronym is sometimes used to criticize a perceived belief system associated with Big Tech.[3][4][5]

				<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><script>function mfTempOpenSection(id){var block=document.getElementById("mf-section-"+id);block.className+=" open-block";block.previousSibling.className+=" open-block";}</script><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><section class="mf-section-0" id="mf-section-0">
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p><p><b>TESCREAL</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Acronym" title="Acronym">acronym</a> <a href="/wiki/Neologism" title="Neologism">neologism</a> proposed by computer scientist <a href="/wiki/Timnit_Gebru" title="Timnit Gebru">Timnit Gebru</a> and philosopher <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_P._Torres" title="Émile P. Torres">Émile P. Torres</a> that stands for "<a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">transhumanism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Extropianism" title="Extropianism">extropianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singularitarianism" title="Singularitarianism">singularitarianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_de_Garis#Cosmism" title="Hugo de Garis">cosmism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">rationalism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Effective_altruism" title="Effective altruism">effective altruism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Longtermism" title="Longtermism">longtermism</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Gebru and Torres argue that these ideologies should be treated as an "interconnected and overlapping" group with shared origins.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They say this is a movement that allows its proponents to use the threat of <a href="/wiki/Human_extinction" title="Human extinction">human extinction</a> to justify expensive or detrimental projects. They consider it pervasive in social and academic circles in <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a> centered around <a href="/wiki/Artificial_intelligence" title="Artificial intelligence">artificial intelligence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dig1_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dig1-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As such, the acronym is sometimes used to criticize a perceived belief system associated with <a href="/wiki/Big_Tech" title="Big Tech">Big Tech</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dig1_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dig1-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Artificial_General_Intelligence_(AGI)"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)</span></a></li>

</li>

</section><div class="mw-heading mw-heading2 section-heading" onclick="mfTempOpenSection(1)"><span class="indicator mf-icon mf-icon-expand mf-icon--small"></span><h2 id="Origin">Origin</h2><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Origin" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div><section class="mf-section-1 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-1">
<p>Gebru and Torres coined "TESCREAL" in 2023, first using it in a draft of a paper titled "The TESCREAL bundle: Eugenics and the promise of utopia through artificial general intelligence".<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/First_Monday_(journal)" title="First Monday (journal)"><i>First Monday</i></a> published the paper in April 2024, though Torres and Gebru popularized the term elsewhere before the paper's publication. According to Gebru and Torres, transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, (modern) cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism are a "bundle" of "interconnected and overlapping ideologies" that emerged from 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Eugenics" title="Eugenics">eugenics</a>, with shared progenitors.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They use the term "TESCREAList" to refer to people who subscribe to, or appear to endorse, most or all of the ideologies captured in the acronym.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dig1_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dig1-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
</section><div class="mw-heading mw-heading2 section-heading" onclick="mfTempOpenSection(2)"><span class="indicator mf-icon mf-icon-expand mf-icon--small"></span><h2 id="Analysis">Analysis</h2><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Analysis" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div><section class="mf-section-2 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-2">
<p>According to critics of these philosophies, TESCREAL describes overlapping movements endorsed by prominent people in the tech industry to provide intellectual backing to pursue and prioritize projects including <a href="/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence" title="Artificial general intelligence">artificial general intelligence (AGI)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Life_extension" title="Life extension">life extension</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Space_colonization" title="Space colonization">space colonization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:3_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Science fiction author <a href="/wiki/Charles_Stross" title="Charles Stross">Charles Stross</a>, using the example of space colonization, argued that the ideologies allow billionaires to pursue massive personal projects driven by a right-wing interpretation of science fiction by arguing that not to pursue such projects poses an <a href="/wiki/Existential_risk_studies#Existential_risk" title="Existential risk studies">existential risk</a> to society.<sup id="cite_ref-:9_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:9-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Gebru and Torres write that, using the threat of extinction, TESCREALists can justify "attempts to build unscoped systems which are inherently unsafe".<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Media scholar <a href="/wiki/Ethan_Zuckerman" title="Ethan Zuckerman">Ethan Zuckerman</a> argues that by only considering goals that are valuable to the TESCREAL movement, futuristic projects with more immediate drawbacks, such as racial inequity, <a href="/wiki/Algorithmic_bias" title="Algorithmic bias">algorithmic bias</a>, and environmental degradation, can be justified.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Speaking at <a href="/wiki/Radio_New_Zealand" title="Radio New Zealand">Radio New Zealand</a>, politics writer Danyl McLauchlan said that many of these philosophies may have started off with good intentions but might have been pushed "to a point of ridiculousness."<sup id="cite_ref-:13_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>Philosopher Yogi Hale Hendlin has argued that by both ignoring the human causes of societal problems and over-engineering solutions, TESCREALists ignore the context in which many problems arise.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Camille Sojit Pejcha wrote in <i><a href="/wiki/Document_Journal" title="Document Journal">Document Journal</a></i> that TESCREAL is a tool for tech elites to concentrate power.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Spectator" title="The Washington Spectator">The Washington Spectator</a></i>, Dave Troy called TESCREAL an "<a href="/wiki/Consequentialism" title="Consequentialism">ends justifies the means</a>" movement that is antithetical to "democratic, inclusive, fair, patient, and just governance".<sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gil_Duran" title="Gil Duran">Gil Duran</a> wrote that "TESCREAL", "authoritarian technocracy", and "techno-optimism" were phrases used in early 2024 to describe a new ideology emerging in the tech industry.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Gebru, Torres, and others have likened TESCREAL to a secular religion due to its parallels to Christian theology and <a href="/wiki/Eschatology" title="Eschatology">eschatology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dig1_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dig1-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:9_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:9-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:8_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Writers in <a href="/wiki/Current_Affairs_(magazine)" title="Current Affairs (magazine)"><i>Current Affairs</i></a> compared these philosophies and the ensuing <a href="/wiki/Techno-optimism" class="mw-redirect" title="Techno-optimism">techno-optimism</a> to "any other monomaniacal faith... in which doubters are seen as enemies and beliefs are accepted without evidence". They argue pursuing TESCREAL would prevent an actual equitable shared future.<sup id="cite_ref-:11_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:11-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Artificial_General_Intelligence_(AGI)"><span id="Artificial_General_Intelligence_.28AGI.29"></span>Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>Much of the discourse about <a href="/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_general_intelligence" title="Existential risk from artificial general intelligence">existential risk from AGI</a> occurs among supporters of the TESCREAL ideologies.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:2_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:14_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:14-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> TESCREALists are either considered "AI accelerationists", who consider AI the only way to pursue a utopian future where problems are solved, or "AI <a href="/wiki/Doomer" title="Doomer">doomers</a>", who consider <a href="/wiki/AI_alignment" title="AI alignment">AI likely to be unaligned</a> to human survival and likely to cause human extinction.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:8_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite the risk, many doomers consider the development of AGI inevitable and argue that only by developing and aligning AGI first can existential risk be averted.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:14_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:14-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p><p>Gebru has likened the conflict between accelerationists and doomers to a "secular religion selling AGI enabled utopia and apocalypse".<sup id="cite_ref-:8_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Torres and Gebru argue that both groups use hypothetical AI-driven apocalypses and utopian futures to justify unlimited research, development, and deregulation of technology. By considering only far-reaching future consequences, creating hype for unproven technology, and fear-mongering, Torres and Gebru allege TESCREALists distract from the impacts of technology that may adversely affect society, disproportionately harm minorities through <a href="/wiki/Algorithmic_bias" title="Algorithmic bias">algorithmic bias</a>, and have a detrimental <a href="/wiki/Environmental_impacts_of_artificial_intelligence" title="Environmental impacts of artificial intelligence">impact on the environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:14_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:14-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Pharmaceuticals">Pharmaceuticals</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: Pharmaceuticals" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>Neşe Devenot has used the TESCREAL acronym to refer to "global financial and tech elites" who promote new uses of <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drugs" class="mw-redirect" title="Psychedelic drugs">psychedelic drugs</a> as <a href="/wiki/Mental_health" title="Mental health">mental health</a> treatments, not because they want to help people, but so that they can make money on the sale of these pharmaceuticals as part of a plan to increase inequality.<sup id="cite_ref-devenot_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devenot-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Claimed_bias_against_minorities">Claimed bias against minorities</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=5" title="Edit section: Claimed bias against minorities" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>Gebru and Torres claim that TESCREAL ideologies directly originate from 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Eugenics" title="Eugenics">eugenics</a><sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and that the bundle of ideologies advocates a <a href="/wiki/New_eugenics" title="New eugenics">second wave of new eugenics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Others have similarly argued that the TESCREAL ideologies developed from earlier philosophies that were used to justify mass murder and genocide.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:6_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some prominent figures who have contributed to TESCREAL ideologies have been alleged to be racist and sexist.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:5_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> McLauchlan has said that, while "some people in these groups want to genetically engineer superintelligent humans, or replace the entire species with a superior form of intelligence" others "like the effective altruists, for example, most of them are just in it to help very poor people ... they are kind of shocked ... that they've been lumped into this malevolent ... eugenics conspiracy".<sup id="cite_ref-:13_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Criticism_and_debate">Criticism and debate</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=6" title="Edit section: Criticism and debate" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>Writing in <i>Asterisk</i>, a magazine related to effective altruism, Ozy Brennan criticized Gebru's and Torres's grouping of different philosophies as if they were a "monolithic" movement. Brennan argues Torres has misunderstood these different philosophies, and has taken <a href="/wiki/Thought_experiment" title="Thought experiment">philosophical thought experiments</a> out of context.<sup id="cite_ref-:15_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:15-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> James Pethokoukis, of the <a href="/wiki/American_Enterprise_Institute" title="American Enterprise Institute">American Enterprise Institute</a>, disagrees with criticizing proponents of TESCREAL. He argues that the tech billionaires criticized in a <a href="/wiki/Scientific_American" title="Scientific American"><i>Scientific American</i></a> article for allegedly espousing TESCREAL have significantly advanced society.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> McLauchlan has noted that critics of the TESCREAL bundle have objected to what they see as disparate and sometimes conflicting ideologies being grouped together, but opines that TESCREAL is a good way to describe and consolidate many of the "grand bizarre ideologies in Silicon Valley".<sup id="cite_ref-:13_9-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Eli Sennesh and <a href="/wiki/James_Hughes_(sociologist)" title="James Hughes (sociologist)">James Hughes</a>, publishing in the blog for the <a href="/wiki/Transhumanism" title="Transhumanism">transhumanist</a> <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Ethics_and_Emerging_Technologies" title="Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies">Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies</a>, have argued that TESCREAL is a left-wing <a href="/wiki/Conspiracy_theory" title="Conspiracy theory">conspiracy theory</a> that unnecessarily groups disparate philosophies together without understanding the <a href="/wiki/Mutually_exclusive" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutually exclusive">mutually exclusive</a> tenets in each.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to Torres, "If advanced technologies continue to be developed at the current rate, a global-scale catastrophe is almost certainly a matter of when rather than if." Torres believes that "perhaps the only way to actually attain a state of ‘existential security’ is to slow down or completely halt further technological innovation", and criticized the longtermist view that technology, although dangerous, is essential for human civilization to achieve its full potential.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:15_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:15-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Brennan contends that Torres's proposal to slow or halt technological development represents a more extreme position than TESCREAL ideologies, preventing many improvements in quality of life, healthcare, and poverty reduction that technological progress enables.<sup id="cite_ref-:15_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:15-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
</section><div class="mw-heading mw-heading2 section-heading" onclick="mfTempOpenSection(3)"><span class="indicator mf-icon mf-icon-expand mf-icon--small"></span><h2 id="Alleged_TESCREALists">Alleged TESCREALists</h2><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=TESCREAL&action=edit&section=7" title="Edit section: Alleged TESCREALists" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div><section class="mf-section-3 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-3">
<p>Venture capitalist <a href="/wiki/Marc_Andreessen" title="Marc Andreessen">Marc Andreessen</a> has self-identified as a TESCREAList.<sup id="cite_ref-:13_9-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:13-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He published the "<a href="/wiki/Techno-Optimist_Manifesto" title="Techno-Optimist Manifesto">Techno-Optimist Manifesto</a>" in October 2023, which Jag Bhalla and <a href="/wiki/Nathan_J._Robinson" title="Nathan J. Robinson">Nathan J. Robinson</a> have called a "perfect example" of the TESCREAL ideologies.<sup id="cite_ref-:11_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:11-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the document, he argues that more advanced artificial intelligence could save countless future potential lives, and that those working to slow or prevent its development should be condemned as murderers.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Elon_Musk" title="Elon Musk">Elon Musk</a> has been described as sympathetic to some TESCREAL ideologies.<sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:5_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-devenot_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devenot-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In August 2022, Musk tweeted that <a href="/wiki/William_MacAskill" title="William MacAskill">William MacAskill</a>'s longtermist book <i><a href="/wiki/What_We_Owe_the_Future" title="What We Owe the Future">What We Owe the Future</a></i> was a "close match for my philosophy".<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some writers believe Musk's <a href="/wiki/Neuralink" title="Neuralink">Neuralink</a> pursues TESCREAList goals.<sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:7_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some AI experts have complained about the focus of Musk's <a href="/wiki/XAI_(company)" title="XAI (company)">XAI</a> company on existential risk, arguing that it and other AI companies have ties to TESCREAL movements.<sup id="cite_ref-:10_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:10-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:4_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dave Troy believes Musk's <a href="/wiki/Natalism" title="Natalism">natalist</a> views originate from TESCREAL ideals.<sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>It has also been suggested that <a href="/wiki/Peter_Thiel" title="Peter Thiel">Peter Thiel</a> is sympathetic to TESCREAL ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:16_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:16-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Benjamin Svetkey wrote in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a></i> that Thiel and other Silicon Valley CEOs who support the <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump_2024_presidential_campaign" title="Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign">Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign</a> are pushing for policies that would shut down "regulators whose outdated restrictions on things like <a href="/wiki/Human_experimentation" class="mw-redirect" title="Human experimentation">human experimentation</a> are slowing down progress toward a <a href="/wiki/Technotopia" class="mw-redirect" title="Technotopia">technotopian</a> paradise".<sup id="cite_ref-:16_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:16-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sam_Altman" title="Sam Altman">Sam Altman</a> and much of the <a href="/wiki/OpenAI" title="OpenAI">OpenAI</a> board has been described as supporting TESCREAL movements, especially in the context of his attempted <a href="/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI" title="Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI">firing</a> in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:8_13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:8-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Gebru and Torres have urged Altman not to pursue TESCREAL ideals.<sup id="cite_ref-business1_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-business1-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Lorraine Redaud writing in <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Hebdo" title="Charlie Hebdo"><i>Charlie Hebdo</i></a> described Sam Altman and multiple other Silicon Valley executives as supporting TESCREAL ideals.<sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Self-identified transhumanists <a href="/wiki/Nick_Bostrom" title="Nick Bostrom">Nick Bostrom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eliezer_Yudkowsky" title="Eliezer Yudkowsky">Eliezer Yudkowsky</a>, both influential in discussions of existential risk from AI,<sup id="cite_ref-:12_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> have also been described as leaders of the TESCREAL movement.<sup id="cite_ref-financial1_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-financial1-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:2_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Redaud said Bostrom supported some ideals "in line with the TESCREALists movement".<sup id="cite_ref-hebdo_12-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hebdo-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sam_Bankman-Fried" title="Sam Bankman-Fried">Sam Bankman-Fried</a>, former CEO of the <a href="/wiki/FTX" title="FTX">FTX</a> cryptocurrency exchange, was a prominent and self-identified member of the effective altruist community.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, since <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy_of_FTX" title="Bankruptcy of FTX">FTX's collapse</a>, administrators of the bankruptcy estate have been trying to recoup about $5 million that they allege was transferred to a nonprofit to help secure the purchase of a historic hotel that has been repurposed for conferences and workshops associated with longtermism, rationalism, and effective altruism. The property hosted liberal eugenicists and other speakers the <i>Guardian</i> said had racist and misogynistic histories.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_20-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap">: <span title="Page: 1
Quotation: "The revelations cast new light on so-called 'Tescreal' intellectual movements – an umbrella term for a cluster of movements including EA and rationalism that exercise broad influence in Silicon Valley, and have the ear of the likes of Sam Altman, Marc Andreessen and Elon Musk. It also raises questions about the extent to which people within that movement continue to benefit from Bankman-Fried’s fraud, the largest in US history."" class="tooltip tooltip-dashed" style="border-bottom: 1px dashed;">1</span> </sup>
</p><p>Longtermist and effective altruist <a href="/wiki/William_MacAskill" title="William MacAskill">William MacAskill</a>, who frequently collaborated with Bankman-Fried to coordinate philanthropic initiatives, has been described as a TESCREAList.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-was1_4-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-was1-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_8-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-devenot_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-devenot-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

readabilityObject.title: TESCREAL
readabilityObject.content:
TESCREAL is an acronym neologism proposed by computer scientist Timnit Gebru and philosopher Émile P. Torres that stands for "transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism".[1][2] Gebru and Torres argue that these ideologies should be treated as an "interconnected and overlapping" group with shared origins.[1] They say this is a movement that allows its proponents to use the threat of human extinction to justify expensive or detrimental projects. They consider it pervasive in social and academic circles in Silicon Valley centered around artificial intelligence.[3] As such, the acronym is sometimes used to criticize a perceived belief system associated with Big Tech.[3][4][5]

Gebru and Torres coined "TESCREAL" in 2023, first using it in a draft of a paper titled "The TESCREAL bundle: Eugenics and the promise of utopia through artificial general intelligence".[1][4] First Monday published the paper in April 2024, though Torres and Gebru popularized the term elsewhere before the paper's publication. According to Gebru and Torres, transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, (modern) cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism are a "bundle" of "interconnected and overlapping ideologies" that emerged from 20th-century eugenics, with shared progenitors.[1] They use the term "TESCREAList" to refer to people who subscribe to, or appear to endorse, most or all of the ideologies captured in the acronym.[1][3]

According to critics of these philosophies, TESCREAL describes overlapping movements endorsed by prominent people in the tech industry to provide intellectual backing to pursue and prioritize projects including artificial general intelligence (AGI), life extension, and space colonization.[1][4][6] Science fiction author Charles Stross, using the example of space colonization, argued that the ideologies allow billionaires to pursue massive personal projects driven by a right-wing interpretation of science fiction by arguing that not to pursue such projects poses an existential risk to society.[7] Gebru and Torres write that, using the threat of extinction, TESCREALists can justify "attempts to build unscoped systems which are inherently unsafe".[1] Media scholar Ethan Zuckerman argues that by only considering goals that are valuable to the TESCREAL movement, futuristic projects with more immediate drawbacks, such as racial inequity, algorithmic bias, and environmental degradation, can be justified.[8] Speaking at Radio New Zealand, politics writer Danyl McLauchlan said that many of these philosophies may have started off with good intentions but might have been pushed "to a point of ridiculousness."[9]

Philosopher Yogi Hale Hendlin has argued that by both ignoring the human causes of societal problems and over-engineering solutions, TESCREALists ignore the context in which many problems arise.[10] Camille Sojit Pejcha wrote in Document Journal that TESCREAL is a tool for tech elites to concentrate power.[6] In The Washington Spectator, Dave Troy called TESCREAL an "ends justifies the means" movement that is antithetical to "democratic, inclusive, fair, patient, and just governance".[4] Gil Duran wrote that "TESCREAL", "authoritarian technocracy", and "techno-optimism" were phrases used in early 2024 to describe a new ideology emerging in the tech industry.[11]

Gebru, Torres, and others have likened TESCREAL to a secular religion due to its parallels to Christian theology and eschatology.[1][3][12][7][13] Writers in Current Affairs compared these philosophies and the ensuing techno-optimism to "any other monomaniacal faith... in which doubters are seen as enemies and beliefs are accepted without evidence". They argue pursuing TESCREAL would prevent an actual equitable shared future.[14]

Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

edit

Much of the discourse about existential risk from AGI occurs among supporters of the TESCREAL ideologies.[8][15][16] TESCREALists are either considered "AI accelerationists", who consider AI the only way to pursue a utopian future where problems are solved, or "AI doomers", who consider AI likely to be unaligned to human survival and likely to cause human extinction.[8][13] Despite the risk, many doomers consider the development of AGI inevitable and argue that only by developing and aligning AGI first can existential risk be averted.[17][16]

Gebru has likened the conflict between accelerationists and doomers to a "secular religion selling AGI enabled utopia and apocalypse".[13] Torres and Gebru argue that both groups use hypothetical AI-driven apocalypses and utopian futures to justify unlimited research, development, and deregulation of technology. By considering only far-reaching future consequences, creating hype for unproven technology, and fear-mongering, Torres and Gebru allege TESCREALists distract from the impacts of technology that may adversely affect society, disproportionately harm minorities through algorithmic bias, and have a detrimental impact on the environment.[5][12][16]

Neşe Devenot has used the TESCREAL acronym to refer to "global financial and tech elites" who promote new uses of psychedelic drugs as mental health treatments, not because they want to help people, but so that they can make money on the sale of these pharmaceuticals as part of a plan to increase inequality.[18]

Claimed bias against minorities

edit

Gebru and Torres claim that TESCREAL ideologies directly originate from 20th-century eugenics[1] and that the bundle of ideologies advocates a second wave of new eugenics.[1][19] Others have similarly argued that the TESCREAL ideologies developed from earlier philosophies that were used to justify mass murder and genocide.[6][17] Some prominent figures who have contributed to TESCREAL ideologies have been alleged to be racist and sexist.[15][20][21] McLauchlan has said that, while "some people in these groups want to genetically engineer superintelligent humans, or replace the entire species with a superior form of intelligence" others "like the effective altruists, for example, most of them are just in it to help very poor people ... they are kind of shocked ... that they've been lumped into this malevolent ... eugenics conspiracy".[9]

Criticism and debate

edit

Writing in Asterisk, a magazine related to effective altruism, Ozy Brennan criticized Gebru's and Torres's grouping of different philosophies as if they were a "monolithic" movement. Brennan argues Torres has misunderstood these different philosophies, and has taken philosophical thought experiments out of context.[22] James Pethokoukis, of the American Enterprise Institute, disagrees with criticizing proponents of TESCREAL. He argues that the tech billionaires criticized in a Scientific American article for allegedly espousing TESCREAL have significantly advanced society.[23] McLauchlan has noted that critics of the TESCREAL bundle have objected to what they see as disparate and sometimes conflicting ideologies being grouped together, but opines that TESCREAL is a good way to describe and consolidate many of the "grand bizarre ideologies in Silicon Valley".[9] Eli Sennesh and James Hughes, publishing in the blog for the transhumanist Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies, have argued that TESCREAL is a left-wing conspiracy theory that unnecessarily groups disparate philosophies together without understanding the mutually exclusive tenets in each.[24]

According to Torres, "If advanced technologies continue to be developed at the current rate, a global-scale catastrophe is almost certainly a matter of when rather than if." Torres believes that "perhaps the only way to actually attain a state of ‘existential security’ is to slow down or completely halt further technological innovation", and criticized the longtermist view that technology, although dangerous, is essential for human civilization to achieve its full potential.[25][22] Brennan contends that Torres's proposal to slow or halt technological development represents a more extreme position than TESCREAL ideologies, preventing many improvements in quality of life, healthcare, and poverty reduction that technological progress enables.[22]

Alleged TESCREALists

edit

Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen has self-identified as a TESCREAList.[9][8] He published the "Techno-Optimist Manifesto" in October 2023, which Jag Bhalla and Nathan J. Robinson have called a "perfect example" of the TESCREAL ideologies.[14] In the document, he argues that more advanced artificial intelligence could save countless future potential lives, and that those working to slow or prevent its development should be condemned as murderers.[6][8]

Elon Musk has been described as sympathetic to some TESCREAL ideologies.[5][12][20][18] In August 2022, Musk tweeted that William MacAskill's longtermist book What We Owe the Future was a "close match for my philosophy".[26] Some writers believe Musk's Neuralink pursues TESCREAList goals.[5][27] Some AI experts have complained about the focus of Musk's XAI company on existential risk, arguing that it and other AI companies have ties to TESCREAL movements.[28][29] Dave Troy believes Musk's natalist views originate from TESCREAL ideals.[4]

It has also been suggested that Peter Thiel is sympathetic to TESCREAL ideas.[5][12][30] Benjamin Svetkey wrote in The Hollywood Reporter that Thiel and other Silicon Valley CEOs who support the Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign are pushing for policies that would shut down "regulators whose outdated restrictions on things like human experimentation are slowing down progress toward a technotopian paradise".[30]

Sam Altman and much of the OpenAI board has been described as supporting TESCREAL movements, especially in the context of his attempted firing in 2023.[12][31][13] Gebru and Torres have urged Altman not to pursue TESCREAL ideals.[32] Lorraine Redaud writing in Charlie Hebdo described Sam Altman and multiple other Silicon Valley executives as supporting TESCREAL ideals.[12]

Self-identified transhumanists Nick Bostrom and Eliezer Yudkowsky, both influential in discussions of existential risk from AI,[21] have also been described as leaders of the TESCREAL movement.[5][15][21] Redaud said Bostrom supported some ideals "in line with the TESCREALists movement".[12]

Sam Bankman-Fried, former CEO of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was a prominent and self-identified member of the effective altruist community.[33] According to The Guardian, since FTX's collapse, administrators of the bankruptcy estate have been trying to recoup about $5 million that they allege was transferred to a nonprofit to help secure the purchase of a historic hotel that has been repurposed for conferences and workshops associated with longtermism, rationalism, and effective altruism. The property hosted liberal eugenicists and other speakers the Guardian said had racist and misogynistic histories.[20]: 1 

Longtermist and effective altruist William MacAskill, who frequently collaborated with Bankman-Fried to coordinate philanthropic initiatives, has been described as a TESCREAList.[1][4][8][18]

  • Utilitarianism
  • The Californian Ideology

First Monday. 29 (4). doi:10.5210/fm.v29i4.13636. ISSN 1396-0466. Archived from the original on July 1, 2024. Retrieved June 27, 2024.
  2. ^ Thomas, Alexander (2024). "Systemic Dehumanization". The Politics and Ethics of Transhumanism. Techno-Human Evolution and Advanced Capitalism (1 ed.). Bristol University Press. pp. 159–194. doi:10.2307/jj.14284473.9. ISBN 978-1-5292-3964-5. JSTOR jj.14284473.9.
  3. ^ a b c d Torres, Émile P (June 15, 2023). "The Acronym Behind Our Wildest AI Dreams and Nightmares". TruthDig. Retrieved October 1, 2023.
  4. ^ a b c d e f Troy, Dave (May 1, 2023). "The Wide Angle: Understanding TESCREAL — the Weird Ideologies Behind Silicon Valley's Rightward Turn". The Washington Spectator. Archived from the original on June 6, 2023. Retrieved October 1, 2023.
  5. ^ a b c d e f Ahuja, Anjana (May 10, 2023). "We need to examine the beliefs of today's tech luminaries". Financial Times. Archived from the original on December 11, 2023. Retrieved October 1, 2023.
  6. ^ a b c d Pejcha, Camille Sojit (May 23, 2024). "Techno-futurists are selling an interplanetary paradise for the posthuman generation—they just forgot about the rest of us". Document Journal. Archived from the original on June 29, 2024. Retrieved June 29, 2024.
  7. ^ a b Stross, Charles (December 20, 2023). "Tech Billionaires Need to Stop Trying to Make the Science Fiction They Grew Up on Real". Scientific American. Archived from the original on June 26, 2024. Retrieved June 27, 2024.
  8. ^ a b c d e f Zuckerman, Ethan (January 16, 2024). "Two warring visions of AI". Prospect. Archived from the original on July 1, 2024. Retrieved June 29, 2024.
  9. ^ a b c d McLauchlan, Danyl (July 6, 2024). "Danyl McLauchlan: Silicon Valley's cult of tech utopianism" (Interview). Interviewed by Susie Ferguson. Radio New Zealand. Retrieved July 6, 2024.
  10. ^ Hendlin, Yogi Hale (April 1, 2024). "Semiocide as Negation: Review of Michael Marder's Dump Philosophy". Biosemiotics. 17 (1): 233–255. doi:10.1007/s12304-024-09558-x. ISSN 1875-1342.
  11. ^ Duran, Gil (February 12, 2024). "The Tech Plutocrats Dreaming of a Right-Wing San Francisco". The New Republic. ISSN 0028-6583. Archived from the original on February 26, 2024. Retrieved August 4, 2024.
  12. ^ a b c d e f g Redaud, Lorraine (August 2, 2024). "TESCREAL, l'idéologie futuriste qui se répand chez les élites de la Silicon Valley". Charlie Hebdo. Retrieved August 7, 2024.
  13. ^ a b c d Piccard, Alexandre (November 30, 2023). "The Sam Altman saga shows that AI doomers have lost a battle". Le Monde. Archived from the original on July 1, 2024. Retrieved June 30, 2024.
  14. ^ a b Bhalla, Jag; Robinson, Nathan J. (October 20, 2023). "'Techno-Optimism' is Not Something You Should Believe In". Current Affairs. ISSN 2471-2647. Retrieved July 2, 2024.
  15. ^ a b c Helfrich, Gina (March 11, 2024). "The harms of terminology: why we should reject so-called "frontier AI"". AI Ethics. doi:10.1007/s43681-024-00438-1. ISSN 2730-5961.
  16. ^ a b c Heaven, Will Douglas (July 10, 2024). "What is AI?". MIT Technology Review. Archived from the original on July 17, 2024. Retrieved August 4, 2024.
  17. ^ a b Van Rensburg, Wessel (June 7, 2024). "AI and the quest for utopia". Vrye Weekblad. Archived from the original on June 30, 2024. Retrieved June 30, 2024.
  18. ^ a b c Devenot, Neşe (December 29, 2023). "TESCREAL hallucinations: Psychedelic and AI hype as inequality engines". Journal of Psychedelic Studies. 7 (S1): 22–39. doi:10.1556/2054.2023.00292. ISSN 2559-9283. Counterfactual efforts to improve mental health by increasing inequality are widespread in the psychedelics industry. These efforts have been propelled by an elitist worldview that is widely-held in Silicon Valley. The backbone of this worldview is the TESCREAL bundle of ideologies, ... While others have noted similarities between the earlier SSRI hype and the ongoing hype for psychedelic medications, the rhetoric of psychedelic hype is tinged with utopian and magico-religious aspirations that have no parallel in the discourse surrounding SSRIs or other antidepressants. I argue that this utopian discourse provides insight into the ways that global financial and tech elites are instrumentalizing psychedelics as one tool in a broader world-building project that justifies increasing material inequality.

readabilityObject.textContent:
TESCREAL is an acronym neologism proposed by computer scientist Timnit Gebru and philosopher Émile P. Torres that stands for "transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism".[1][2] Gebru and Torres argue that these ideologies should be treated as an "interconnected and overlapping" group with shared origins.[1] They say this is a movement that allows its proponents to use the threat of human extinction to justify expensive or detrimental projects. They consider it pervasive in social and academic circles in Silicon Valley centered around artificial intelligence.[3] As such, the acronym is sometimes used to criticize a perceived belief system associated with Big Tech.[3][4][5]




Gebru and Torres coined "TESCREAL" in 2023, first using it in a draft of a paper titled "The TESCREAL bundle: Eugenics and the promise of utopia through artificial general intelligence".[1][4] First Monday published the paper in April 2024, though Torres and Gebru popularized the term elsewhere before the paper's publication. According to Gebru and Torres, transhumanism, extropianism, singularitarianism, (modern) cosmism, rationalism, effective altruism, and longtermism are a "bundle" of "interconnected and overlapping ideologies" that emerged from 20th-century eugenics, with shared progenitors.[1] They use the term "TESCREAList" to refer to people who subscribe to, or appear to endorse, most or all of the ideologies captured in the acronym.[1][3]


According to critics of these philosophies, TESCREAL describes overlapping movements endorsed by prominent people in the tech industry to provide intellectual backing to pursue and prioritize projects including artificial general intelligence (AGI), life extension, and space colonization.[1][4][6] Science fiction author Charles Stross, using the example of space colonization, argued that the ideologies allow billionaires to pursue massive personal projects driven by a right-wing interpretation of science fiction by arguing that not to pursue such projects poses an existential risk to society.[7] Gebru and Torres write that, using the threat of extinction, TESCREALists can justify "attempts to build unscoped systems which are inherently unsafe".[1] Media scholar Ethan Zuckerman argues that by only considering goals that are valuable to the TESCREAL movement, futuristic projects with more immediate drawbacks, such as racial inequity, algorithmic bias, and environmental degradation, can be justified.[8] Speaking at Radio New Zealand, politics writer Danyl McLauchlan said that many of these philosophies may have started off with good intentions but might have been pushed "to a point of ridiculousness."[9] 
Philosopher Yogi Hale Hendlin has argued that by both ignoring the human causes of societal problems and over-engineering solutions, TESCREALists ignore the context in which many problems arise.[10] Camille Sojit Pejcha wrote in Document Journal that TESCREAL is a tool for tech elites to concentrate power.[6] In The Washington Spectator, Dave Troy called TESCREAL an "ends justifies the means" movement that is antithetical to "democratic, inclusive, fair, patient, and just governance".[4] Gil Duran wrote that "TESCREAL", "authoritarian technocracy", and "techno-optimism" were phrases used in early 2024 to describe a new ideology emerging in the tech industry.[11]
Gebru, Torres, and others have likened TESCREAL to a secular religion due to its parallels to Christian theology and eschatology.[1][3][12][7][13] Writers in Current Affairs compared these philosophies and the ensuing techno-optimism to "any other monomaniacal faith... in which doubters are seen as enemies and beliefs are accepted without evidence". They argue pursuing TESCREAL would prevent an actual equitable shared future.[14]

Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

    
edit





Much of the discourse about existential risk from AGI occurs among supporters of the TESCREAL ideologies.[8][15][16] TESCREALists are either considered "AI accelerationists", who consider AI the only way to pursue a utopian future where problems are solved, or "AI doomers", who consider AI likely to be unaligned to human survival and likely to cause human extinction.[8][13] Despite the risk, many doomers consider the development of AGI inevitable and argue that only by developing and aligning AGI first can existential risk be averted.[17][16] 
Gebru has likened the conflict between accelerationists and doomers to a "secular religion selling AGI enabled utopia and apocalypse".[13] Torres and Gebru argue that both groups use hypothetical AI-driven apocalypses and utopian futures to justify unlimited research, development, and deregulation of technology. By considering only far-reaching future consequences, creating hype for unproven technology, and fear-mongering, Torres and Gebru allege TESCREALists distract from the impacts of technology that may adversely affect society, disproportionately harm minorities through algorithmic bias, and have a detrimental impact on the environment.[5][12][16]


Neşe Devenot has used the TESCREAL acronym to refer to "global financial and tech elites" who promote new uses of psychedelic drugs as mental health treatments, not because they want to help people, but so that they can make money on the sale of these pharmaceuticals as part of a plan to increase inequality.[18]

Claimed bias against minorities

    
edit





Gebru and Torres claim that TESCREAL ideologies directly originate from 20th-century eugenics[1] and that the bundle of ideologies advocates a second wave of new eugenics.[1][19] Others have similarly argued that the TESCREAL ideologies developed from earlier philosophies that were used to justify mass murder and genocide.[6][17] Some prominent figures who have contributed to TESCREAL ideologies have been alleged to be racist and sexist.[15][20][21] McLauchlan has said that, while "some people in these groups want to genetically engineer superintelligent humans, or replace the entire species with a superior form of intelligence" others "like the effective altruists, for example, most of them are just in it to help very poor people ... they are kind of shocked ... that they've been lumped into this malevolent ... eugenics conspiracy".[9]

Criticism and debate

    
edit





Writing in Asterisk, a magazine related to effective altruism, Ozy Brennan criticized Gebru's and Torres's grouping of different philosophies as if they were a "monolithic" movement. Brennan argues Torres has misunderstood these different philosophies, and has taken philosophical thought experiments out of context.[22] James Pethokoukis, of the American Enterprise Institute, disagrees with criticizing proponents of TESCREAL. He argues that the tech billionaires criticized in a Scientific American article for allegedly espousing TESCREAL have significantly advanced society.[23] McLauchlan has noted that critics of the TESCREAL bundle have objected to what they see as disparate and sometimes conflicting ideologies being grouped together, but opines that TESCREAL is a good way to describe and consolidate many of the "grand bizarre ideologies in Silicon Valley".[9] Eli Sennesh and James Hughes, publishing in the blog for the transhumanist Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies, have argued that TESCREAL is a left-wing conspiracy theory that unnecessarily groups disparate philosophies together without understanding the mutually exclusive tenets in each.[24]
According to Torres, "If advanced technologies continue to be developed at the current rate, a global-scale catastrophe is almost certainly a matter of when rather than if." Torres believes that "perhaps the only way to actually attain a state of ‘existential security’ is to slow down or completely halt further technological innovation", and criticized the longtermist view that technology, although dangerous, is essential for human civilization to achieve its full potential.[25][22] Brennan contends that Torres's proposal to slow or halt technological development represents a more extreme position than TESCREAL ideologies, preventing many improvements in quality of life, healthcare, and poverty reduction that technological progress enables.[22]

Alleged TESCREALists

    
edit





Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen has self-identified as a TESCREAList.[9][8] He published the "Techno-Optimist Manifesto" in October 2023, which Jag Bhalla and Nathan J. Robinson have called a "perfect example" of the TESCREAL ideologies.[14] In the document, he argues that more advanced artificial intelligence could save countless future potential lives, and that those working to slow or prevent its development should be condemned as murderers.[6][8]
Elon Musk has been described as sympathetic to some TESCREAL ideologies.[5][12][20][18] In August 2022, Musk tweeted that William MacAskill's longtermist book What We Owe the Future was a "close match for my philosophy".[26] Some writers believe Musk's Neuralink pursues TESCREAList goals.[5][27] Some AI experts have complained about the focus of Musk's XAI company on existential risk, arguing that it and other AI companies have ties to TESCREAL movements.[28][29] Dave Troy believes Musk's natalist views originate from TESCREAL ideals.[4]
It has also been suggested that Peter Thiel is sympathetic to TESCREAL ideas.[5][12][30] Benjamin Svetkey wrote in The Hollywood Reporter that Thiel and other Silicon Valley CEOs who support the Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign are pushing for policies that would shut down "regulators whose outdated restrictions on things like human experimentation are slowing down progress toward a technotopian paradise".[30]
Sam Altman and much of the OpenAI board has been described as supporting TESCREAL movements, especially in the context of his attempted firing in 2023.[12][31][13] Gebru and Torres have urged Altman not to pursue TESCREAL ideals.[32] Lorraine Redaud writing in Charlie Hebdo described Sam Altman and multiple other Silicon Valley executives as supporting TESCREAL ideals.[12]
Self-identified transhumanists Nick Bostrom and Eliezer Yudkowsky, both influential in discussions of existential risk from AI,[21] have also been described as leaders of the TESCREAL movement.[5][15][21] Redaud said Bostrom supported some ideals "in line with the TESCREALists movement".[12]
Sam Bankman-Fried, former CEO of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, was a prominent and self-identified member of the effective altruist community.[33]  According to The Guardian, since FTX's collapse, administrators of the bankruptcy estate have been trying to recoup about $5 million that they allege was transferred to a nonprofit to help secure the purchase of a historic hotel that has been repurposed for conferences and workshops associated with longtermism, rationalism, and effective altruism. The property hosted liberal eugenicists and other speakers the Guardian said had racist and misogynistic histories.[20]: 1 
Longtermist and effective altruist William MacAskill, who frequently collaborated with Bankman-Fried to coordinate philanthropic initiatives, has been described as a TESCREAList.[1][4][8][18]
